This traffic study presents the traffic impact analysis for the proposed Orangefair Residential
Development (the “Project”) located in the City of Fullerton. The methodology and base
assumptions used in the analysis were established in conjunction with the City of Fullerton.
The Project site (the “Site”) is located at the northwest corner of Lemon Street & Orangefair
Avenue. The Site is bound by Orangethorpe Avenue to the north, Lemon Street to the east,
Orangefair Avenue to the south, and Harbor Boulevard to the west. The Site is located 0.20
miles north of the Riverside Freeway (SR-91), which provides primary regional access to the
Site. The Site is also located 1.0 miles south of the Fullerton Metrolink Station, which provides
rail service to Los Angeles, Oceanside, and Riverside. Access to the Site is provided via
driveways on Orangefair Avenue and Lemon Street. The Site also lies adjacent to the
Orangefair Mall and its footprint currently serves as ground level parking on the southern portion
Trammell Crow Residential is proposing to construct a 323-unit apartment complex adjacent to
the existing Orangefair Mall. Access to the Site will be provided via three existing driveways
located on Orangefair Avenue (two driveways) and Lemon Street (one driveway). The Project is
also proposing to construct two new multi-level parking garages to serve the future residents of
the Project, with additional shared parking for the shopping mall. The Project site plan is
As required by the City of Fullerton, the study intersections were analyzed using the 2000
Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) methodology (Transportation Research Board, 2000). The
Traffix software was used to calculate the overall intersection delay (seconds) and the resulting
level of service (LOS). LOS is a qualitative measure used to describe traffic flow conditions. Table
1 presents a description of the LOS categories, which range from excellent, nearly free-flow traffic
at LOS A to stop-and-go conditions at LOS F. For reporting of analysis results, the LOS is based
on average vehicular delay where the volume to capacity ration (V/C) is less than 1.000. If the
V/C ratio is greater than 1.000, the LOS is considered to be failing (LOS F).
The base assumptions and technical methodologies (i.e., trip generation, study locations, analysis
methodology, growth rates, related projects, etc.) were identified as part of the study approach
and were approved by the City’s traffic engineer and planning department.
Additionally, variables used in the analyses, such as saturation flow rates, traffic signal timings,
and peak hour factors, were made consistent with the worksheet output from the City’s General
The traffic impact study evaluates the potential for impacts caused by the Project on the street
system surrounding the Project site. The following scenarios are analyzed for the Project:
 Existing Conditions (Year 2013) – The analysis of existing traffic conditions provides a
basis for the assessment of existing plus project and future traffic conditions. The
Existing Conditions analysis includes a description of key area streets and highways,
traffic volumes, and current operating conditions.
Intersection turning movement counts for weekday morning and afternoon peak hours
were collected in November 2011, February 2012, and February 2013 and April 2013.
Field review data (lane configurations, signal phasing, parking restrictions, etc.) for the
analyzed intersections was collected in March 2013.
 Existing with Project Conditions (Year 2013) – The California Environmental Quality Act
(CEQA) and the City of Fullerton require an evaluation of project traffic impacts on the
existing environment as part of traffic impact analyses. This analysis evaluates the
potential Project-related traffic impacts as compared to existing conditions.
 Future without Project Conditions (Opening Year 2016) – This analysis projects the
future traffic growth and intersection operating conditions that could be expected as a
result of regional growth and related projects in the vicinity of the Site by year 2016. The
Future without Project traffic conditions are projected by adding ambient traffic growth
and traffic from related projects to existing conditions. This analysis provides the
baseline conditions by which Project impacts are evaluated at the Project’s opening
 Future with Project Conditions (Opening Year 2016) – This analysis identifies the
potential incremental impacts of the Project at full buildout, prior to mitigation, on
projected future traffic operating conditions by adding the Project-generated traffic to the
 Future without Project Conditions (Full Buildout Year 2030) – This analysis projects the
future traffic growth and intersection operating conditions that could be expected as a
result of regional growth and related projects in the vicinity of the Site by year 2030. The
Future without Project traffic conditions are projected by adding ambient traffic growth
and traffic from related projects to existing conditions. This analysis provides the
baseline conditions by which Project impacts are evaluated at full buildout.
 Future with Project Conditions (Full Buildout Year 2030) – This analysis identifies the
potential incremental impacts of the Project at full buildout, prior to mitigation, on
projected future traffic operating conditions by adding the Project-generated traffic to the
Based on our discussions with the City of Fullerton, a significant traffic impact occurs when the
analysis determines that traffic attributable to a proposed project decreases intersection
performance during the peak hour from an acceptable LOS (A, B, C, or D) to a deficient LOS (E
The Congestion Management Program (CMP) is a state-mandated program that serves as the
monitoring and analytical basis for transportation funding decisions in the county made through
the Regional Transportation Improvement Program (RTIP) and State Transportation
Improvement Program (STIP) processes. The CMP requires that a Traffic Impact Analysis (TIA)
be performed for all CMP Highway System (CMPHS) intersections where a Project would add
2,400 daily trips or 1,600 daily trips if the Project has direct access to the CMPHS.
The CMP required for the Project has been performed, in Chapter 9, in accordance with the TIA
guidelines referenced in the Congestion Management Program Preparation Manual (Orange
This report is divided into 10 chapters, including this introduction. Chapter 2 describes the
existing circulation system, traffic volumes, and traffic conditions in the Study Area. The
methodologies used to forecast future background traffic volumes are described and applied in
Chapter 3. Chapter 4 discusses the methodologies used to forecast Project traffic and the
Project-related traffic volumes. Chapter 5 assesses intersection operating conditions of the
existing street system after completion of the Project, while Chapter 6 assesses intersection
operating conditions of the future street system after completion of the Project. Chapter 7
identifies traffic impacts caused by the Project under existing and future conditions of the
opening year and buildout year. Chapter 8 presents the regional Congestion Management
Program analysis. Chapter 9 evaluates the site access and internal circulation. Chapter 10
summarizes the analyses and study conclusions. The appendices contain supporting
documentation, traffic counts, and intersection capacity calculation worksheets.
Source: Highway Capacity Manual, Special Report 209,Transportation Research Board, 2000.
A comprehensive data collection effort was undertaken to develop a detailed description of
existing conditions in the Project Study Area. The existing conditions analysis relevant to this
study includes an assessment of the existing street system and an analysis of traffic volumes
The Study Area generally includes a geographic area approximately two miles (north-south) by
approximately two miles (east-west). This Study Area was established in consultation with the
City of Fullerton and by reviewing the existing intersection/corridor operations, Project peak hour
vehicle trip generation, the anticipated distribution of Project vehicular trips, and the potential
A traffic analysis study area generally comprises those locations with the greatest potential to
experience significant traffic impacts, as defined by the lead agency, due to a project. In the traffic
engineering practice, a study area generally includes those intersections that are:
1. Immediately adjacent or in close proximity to the project site
2. In the vicinity of the project site that are documented to have current or projected future
3. In the vicinity of the project site that are forecast to experience a relatively greater
percentage of project-related vehicular turning movements (e.g., at freeway ramp
The Project Study Area was designed to ensure that all potentially significantly impacted
intersections, prior to any mitigation, were analyzed, and the boundary of the Study Area was
extended, as necessary, to confirm that there were no significant impacts at or outside the
boundary of the Study Area by reviewing the Project traffic’s travel patterns.
A total of 16 signalized intersections in the Study Area were identified by the City of Fullerton for
detailed analysis of the above conditions. Of the 16 intersections, 14 are located within the City
of Fullerton and two are located within the City of Anaheim. Also, the east side of Lemon Street
south of Freedom Avenue is within the City of Anaheim. Four of the 15 intersections located
within the City of Fullerton are freeway ramp locations and share jurisdiction with Caltrans. The
following 16 intersections were selected for analysis:
Figure 2 illustrates the location of the Site in relation to the surrounding street system and the 16
The existing street system in the Study Area consists of a regional roadway system including
freeways, major arterials, primary arterials, secondary arterials, local collector streets, and
residential streets. The secondary arterials, local collectors, and selected residential streets in
the Study Area offer sub-regional and local access and circulation opportunities. These
transportation facilities generally provide two to six travel lanes and usually allow parking on
either side of the street. Typically, the speed limits range between 25 and 45 miles per hour
(mph) on the major, primary, and secondary arterials, collector, and local collector streets and
The Project Site is located 0.20 miles north of the SR-91, which runs generally in the east-west
direction and provides primary regional access to the Project Site.
The major arterials providing regional and sub-regional access to the Project vicinity include
Harbor Boulevard, Lemon Street, Chapman Avenue, and Orangethorpe Avenue. The following is
a brief description of the major streets in the Study Area:
Street – Euclid Street is a designated Primary Arterial north of Orangethorpe
Avenue and a Major Arterial south of Orangethorpe Avenue that runs in the north-south
direction and is located west of the Site. It provides sub-regional access to the Site with
four travel lanes, two in each direction, and left-turn lanes at intersections. On-street
parking is not permitted. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.
Boulevard – Harbor Boulevard is a designated Major Arterial that runs in the north-
south direction and is located adjacent to the western boundary of the Site. It provides
regional and sub-regional access to the Site with four to six travel lanes, two to three in
each direction, and left-turn lanes at intersections. On-street parking is not permitted. The
Street – Lemon Street is a designated Primary Arterial between Orangethorpe
Avenue and Chapman Avenue and a designated Major Arterial between Orangethorpe
Avenue and the SR-91 that runs in the north-south direction and is located adjacent to the
eastern boundary of the Site. It provides regional and sub-regional access to the Site with
four travel lanes, two in each direction, and left-turn lanes at intersections. On-street
parking is not permitted. The posted speed limit is 30 to 35 mph. The Project proposes to
utilize one driveway on Lemon Street.
Avenue – Raymond Avenue is a designated Primary Arterial that runs in the
north-south direction and is located east of the Site. It provides sub-regional access to the
Site with four travel lanes, two in each direction, and left-turn lanes at intersections. On-
street parking is not permitted. The posted speed limit is 35 to 40 mph.
Avenue – Chapman Avenue is a designated Primary Arterial that runs in the
east-west direction and is located north of the Site. It provides sub-regional access to the
Site with four travel lanes, two in each direction, and left-turn lanes at intersections. On-
street parking is not permitted. The posted speed limit is 30 mph.
Avenue – Commonwealth Avenue is a designated Primary Arterial that
runs in the east-west direction and is located north of the Site. It provides sub-regional
access to the Site with four travel lanes, two in each direction, and left-turn lanes at
intersections. On-street parking is available. The posted speed limit is 30 to 35 mph.
Avenue – Orangethorpe Avenue is a designated Major Arterial that runs in
the east-west direction and is located adjacent to the northern boundary of the Site. It
provides regional and sub-regional access to the Site with six travel lanes, three in each
direction, and left-turn lanes at intersections. On-street parking is not permitted. The
posted speed limit is 35 to 45 mph.
Avenue – Orangefair Avenue is a designated local collector street that runs in
the east-west direction and is located adjacent to the southern boundary of the Site. It
provides access to the Site with two travel lanes, one in each direction, and left-turn lanes
at intersections. On-street parking is not permitted. The posted speed limit is 40 mph. The
Project proposes to utilize two driveways on Orangefair Avenue.
 La Palma Avenue – La Palma is a designated Primary Arterial that runs in the east-west
direction and is located south of the Site. It provides sub-regional access to the Site with
four travel lanes, two in each direction, and left-turn lanes at intersections. On-street
parking is not permitted. The posted speed limit is 35 mph.
The existing lane configurations at the study intersections are provided in Appendix A.
The Project area is served by trains operated by Metrolink and bus lines operated by OCTA.
The Fullerton Metrolink station is located one mile north of the Site and provides rail service to Los
Angeles, Oceanside, and Riverside. Service is provided during commuter morning and afternoon
Bus transit service in the Project vicinity is available along the following streets:
The following provides a brief description of the bus lines providing service in Project vicinity:
30 – Route 30 travels in the east-west direction on Orangethorpe Avenue in the
vicinity of the Site with headways of 45 minutes during the weekday morning and
afternoon peak hours. The line travels from Anaheim to Cerritos and provides service to
43 – Route 43 travels north-south on Harbor Boulevard in the vicinity of the Site
with headways of 15 minutes during the weekday morning and afternoon peak hours. The
line travels from Fullerton to Costa Mesa and provides service to Anaheim, Garden Grove,
47 – Route 47 travels north-south on Lemon Street in the vicinity of the Site with
headways of 15 minutes during the weekday morning peak hours and 10 minutes during
the weekday afternoon peak hours. The line travels from Fullerton to Newport Beach and
provides service to Anaheim, Orange, and Santa Ana.

text.b: EXISTING TRAFFIC VOLUMES AND INTERSECTION OPERATIONS

page.text: This section presents the existing peak hour turning movement traffic volumes for the
intersections analyzed in the study, describes the methodology used to assess the traffic
conditions at each intersection, and analyzes the resulting operating conditions at each
intersection indicating average vehicular delay, V/C ratios, and LOS.
Intersection turning movement counts were conducted at the 16 study intersections during the
weekday morning and afternoon peak hours in November 2011, February 2012, and February
and April 2013. Intersection turning movement count worksheets are provided in Appendix B.
Traffic count data which is less than 2 years old is considered acceptable for use in analysis.
The City provided a portion of the count data for the Study Area, while the remainder of the data
was newly collected. For older data, in order to reflect year 2013 conditions, traffic volumes
conducted in 2011 were increased by 1.00% for through movements and 0.50% for turning
movements; and traffic counts conducted in 2012 were increased by 0.50% for major
movements and 0.25% for minor movements. This methodology ensures older counts are
equitably balanced with more current counts. All data used in this study is less than 2 years old.
The existing traffic volumes for the 16 study intersections are illustrated in Figure 3 and were
analyzed to determine the existing operating conditions at the 16 study intersections.
Table 2 summarizes the morning and afternoon average delays and the corresponding LOS for
each of the 16 study intersections under Existing Conditions. As summarized in Table 2, all 16
study intersections operate at LOS D or better during both the morning and afternoon peak
The LOS calculation worksheets can be found in Appendix C.

page.text: LOS is based on the average delay where the V/C is less than 1.000. If the V/C ratio is greater than
1.000, the LOS is based on the V/C ratio (LOS F).
Estimates of future traffic conditions both with and without the Project were developed to evaluate
the potential impacts of the Project on the local street system. This discussion details the
assumptions used to develop the Future without Project conditions (opening year 2016 and year

text.b: CEQA GUIDELINES REGARDING FUTURE TRAFFIC CONDITIONS

page.text: The forecast of Future without Project conditions was prepared in accordance with procedures
outlined in Section 15130 of Guidelines for Implementation of the California Environmental Quality
Act, Chapter 3, Title 14, California Code of Regulations (California Natural Resources Agency,
amended July 27, 2007). Specifically, Guidelines provides two options for developing the
“(A) A list of past, present, and probable future projects producing related or
cumulative impacts, including, if necessary, those projects outside the control of
(B) A summary of projections contained in an adopted general plan or related
planning document, or in a prior environmental document which has been adopted
or certified, which described or evaluated regional or area wide conditions
contributing to the cumulative impact. Any such planning document shall be
referenced and made available to the public at a location specified by the lead
Accordingly, the traffic analysis provides a highly conservative estimate of Future without Project
traffic volumes as it incorporates both the “A” and “B” options outlined in Guidelines for purposes
No improvements to the existing circulation system are assumed prior to analysis, including lane
The Future without Project traffic projections reflect growth in traffic over existing conditions
from two sources. The first source is the ambient growth in traffic, which reflects increases in
traffic due to regional growth and development outside the Study Area. The second source is
growth due to traffic generated by projects which are proposed, approved, or under construction
within and in the vicinity of the Study Area (collectively, the “Related Projects”).
Existing traffic is expected to increase as a result of regional growth and development. Based
on historic trends and in consultation with the City of Fullerton, growth factors of 1.50% for
through movements and 0.80% for turning movements were used to increase the existing traffic
volumes to reflect the effects of regional growth and development by the opening year 2016.
Growth factors of 10% for through movements and 5.0% for turn movements were applied to
the existing traffic volumes to reflect the effects of regional growth and development by the full
buildout year 2030. These growth factors were supplied by the City of Fullerton General Plan
In accordance with CEQA requirements, this study considers the effects of the Project in
relation to other developments either proposed, approved, or under construction in the Study
Area and expected to be implemented prior to the buildout date of the Project. Related Project
information was obtained from the City of Fullerton. Though the ambient growth factor described
above is intended to account for total traffic growth within the Study Area, the effect of Related
Project traffic is included as well, both to maintain a conservative analysis of future conditions
and to include the specific effects of known future traffic generators at nearby study
intersections. Related Project traffic forecasts for both the opening year 2016 and full buildout
year 2030 were developed from the City of Fullerton General Plan traffic model data for each of
the 16 study intersections. The following Related Projects were included in the traffic forecasts:
 Valencia Grove Townhomes at Amerige Heights
The resulting Future without Project peak hour traffic volumes for opening year 2016 and full
buildout year 2030 are illustrated in Figures 4 and 5.
Similar to the analysis presented in Chapter 2, the study intersections were analyzed using the
HCM methodology required by the City of Fullerton.

This Chapter describes the assumptions and methodology used in developing the traffic
volumes associated with the Project within the Study Area.
As described in Chapter 1, the Project proposes to construct a 323-unit apartment complex
adjacent to the existing Orangefair Mall. The Project will contain a variety of market rate
apartment units that will range in size from studios to multiple-bedroom units. Access to the Site
will be provided via three existing shopping mall driveways, two driveways located on
Orangefair Avenue and one driveway located on Lemon Street. An existing driveway on the
extreme southeastern corner of the shopping mall will be eliminated with the Project. The
Project is also proposing to construct two new multi-level parking structures to accommodate
the future residents of the Project.
The first step of the forecasting process is trip generation, which estimates the total arriving and
departing vehicular trips generated by the Project on a peak hour and daily basis by applying the
appropriate vehicle trip generation equations, or rates, to the density of Project development.
The second step of the forecasting process is trip distribution, which identifies the origins and
destinations of inbound and outbound Project trips. These origins and destinations are typically
based on demographics and existing/anticipated travel patterns in the Study Area. Localized
routes of travel through the Study Area are developed based on existing traffic patterns and
relative travel times on various corridors.
The third step of the forecasting process is traffic assignment. This involves applying the traffic
generated by the Project (the trip generation) to the intersections and street segments in the
Study Area according to the projected trip distribution patterns. These traffic volumes can then be
added to existing or future background conditions to represent traffic volumes once the Project is
With the forecasting process complete and Project traffic assignments developed, the impact of
the proposed Project is isolated by comparing operational (i.e., LOS) conditions at the study
intersections using expected future traffic volumes without and with forecast Project traffic. The
need for site-specific and/or cumulative local area traffic improvements can then be evaluated and
the significance of the Project’s impacts identified.
The most recent trip generation rate from the Trip Generation, 9
Transportation Engineers [ITE], 2012) for Land Use Code 220 (Apartments) was used to
develop the Project trip generation estimates. A mixed-use trip generation credit was calculated
for the Project by using an ITE mixed-use and internal capture spreadsheet. This process
adjusts vehicle trips based on the potential for walking to adjacent uses or to account for
multiple destination trips. The mixed-use credit is applied to reduce double-counting of vehicles.
The ITE mixed-use output estimates an 11% reduction of Project traffic in the morning peak
hour and 28% in the evening. However, to remain conservative, 10% was applied to the
morning and 15% to the evening. The results of the ITE mixed-use analysis is provided in
As summarized in Table 5, the Project is anticipated to generate 2,081 daily trips, with 146 trips
(29 inbound, 117 outbound) during the morning peak hour and 166 trips (108 inbound, 58
outbound) during the afternoon peak hour.
Project traffic volumes both entering and exiting the Site have been distributed to the local street
system based on the location of nearby commercial and employment centers, characteristics of
the street system serving the Project Site, and land uses associated with each of the Project
driveways. The general distribution pattern was reviewed and approved by the City of Fullerton.
Project traffic was assigned to the surrounding street system based on the following distribution
 15% was assigned to/from the north on Harbor Boulevard and Lemon Street
 25% was assigned to/from the east on SR-91 Eastbound
 5% was assigned to/from the east on Orangethorpe Avenue
 15% was assigned to/from the south on Harbor Boulevard and Lemon Street
 35% was assigned to/from the west on SR-91 Westbound
 5% was assigned to/from the west on Orangethorpe Avenue
The general and detailed distribution of Project traffic through the study intersections are
The trip distribution pattern was applied to the trip generation estimates summarized in Table 5
to develop the Project-only traffic through the 16 study intersections. Figure 7 illustrates the
Project-only peak hour traffic volumes at the driveways and study intersections.
[a] Source: Trip Generation, 9th Edition, Institute of Transportation Engineers, 2012.
[b] Trip generation estimate based on the best-fit curve formula.
[c] Reduction taken for mixed-use development. See Appendix D for detailed analysis.
This Chapter describes the evaluation of Project traffic on the existing environment. The
analysis of year 2013 corresponds with the Existing conditions data and analysis presented in
Chapter 2. The Existing with Project conditions are defined by the traffic volumes, roadways,
and intersection configurations that exist in year 2013.
The Project-only traffic volumes for the Project described in Chapter 5 and shown in Figure 7
were added to the Existing traffic volumes show in Figure 3. The resulting volumes are
illustrated in Figure 8. They represent Existing with Project conditions after full buildout of the
Project in year 2013. Although the Project is not expected to be constructed until 2016, this
methodology is consistent with the required Existing with Project analysis scenario.
Table 6 summarizes the results of the Existing with Project analysis at the study intersections.
As shown in Table 6, all 16 of the study intersections operate at LOS D or better during both the
morning and afternoon peak hours with the addition of Project-related traffic.

1.000, the LOS is based on the V/C ratio (LOS F).
This Chapter describes the evaluation of the Project traffic on future background traffic. The
analysis year of 2016 corresponds with the anticipated opening year of the Project, and the
analysis year of 2030 corresponds with the full buildout year of the Project. All future background
traffic growth (i.e., ambient and related project traffic growth) presented in Chapter 3 is assumed

text.b: Future with Project (Opening Year 2016) Traffic Volumes

page.text: The Project-only traffic volumes described in Chapter 5 and shown in Figure 7 were added to the
Future without Project (opening year 2016) traffic volumes shown in Figure 4. The resulting traffic
volumes are presented in Figure 9 and represent the Future with Project (opening year 2016)
conditions, i.e., future conditions after the opening of the Project in year 2016.

text.b: Future with Project (Full Buildout Year 2030) Traffic Volumes

page.text: The Project-only traffic volumes described in Chapter 5 and shown in Figure 7 were added to the
Future without Project (full buildout year 2030) traffic volumes shown in Figure 5. The resulting
traffic volumes are presented in Figure 10 and represent the Future with Project full (buildout year
2030) conditions, i.e., future conditions after full buildout of the Project in year 2030.

study intersections. As shown in Table 7, all 16 study intersections operate at LOS D or better
during both the morning and afternoon peak hours under Future with Project (opening year

text.b: Future with Project (Full Buildout Year 2030) Intersection LOS

page.text: Table 8 summarizes the results of the Future with Project (full buildout year 2030) analysis at
the study intersections. As shown in Table 8, nine of the 16 study intersections operate at LOS
D or better during both the morning and afternoon peak hours under Future with Project (full
buildout year 2030) conditions. The remaining seven study intersections operate at LOS E or F
during at least one of the analyzed peak hours.
 Harbor Boulevard & SR-91 WB Ramps (PM peak)
 Harbor Boulevard & La Palma Avenue (PM peak)
